subject: Move watch task out of worker process
commit_message:
Move watch task out of worker process

The periodic watch task start_watch_task for each stack is performed
after the fork when running multiple worker processes, which is
probably not what we want, instead create the watch task in the
constructor (which is called before the fork).  Testing indicates
we only end up with one timer fired due to the common StackWatch
and ThreadGroupManager, but creating the tasks per engine instead
of per worker makes more logical sense.

Also adds a periodic_enable config option, which allows periodic
tasks to be completely disabled.  This is left defaulted to True
for now, but should be set to False for all multi-engine deployments
to avoid stacks with watch rules having multiple periodic tasks
which race to evaluate/action alarms, which is unlikely to work as
StackWatch doesn't use the global stack lock.

This is the first step to deprecating periodic tasks/watch rules
(we can probably default periodic_enable to False after we make the
ceilometer based AWS::CloudWatch::Alarm implementation the default
intead of CWLite, currently blocked on bug #1316842)

Partial-Bug: #1322128

connects to the remote volume before resuming the VM on the destination

subject: Enforce unicode json output for jsonutils.load[s]()
commit_message:
Enforce unicode json output for jsonutils.load[s]()

simplejson module applies some optimizations on ASCII-only unicode
strings which result in non-unicode json output. See details at [1]
and [2]. To make sure we always return consistent json output no
matter which json implementation is used, we should explicitly convert
the input for json.load[s]() to unicode.

If user wants to pass a file object of non UTF-8 encoding to
json.load[s](), she must also specify this encoding as an argument. To
support this scenario too, we've added 'encoding' argument to
jsonutils.load[s]() implementation.

Made all present JSON tests to run on both supported json library
implementations.

Added explicit dependency for simplejson to be able to test different
implementations in unit tests. Distributors still running Python 2.6
are recommended but not required to install simplejson.

Related-Bug: 1314129

[1]: https://code.djangoproject.com/ticket/11742
[2]: https://code.google.com/p/simplejson/issues/detail?id=40

subject: vmware: Fix problems with VIM API retry logic
commit_message:
vmware: Fix problems with VIM API retry logic

Currently the VIM APIs including session creation API are retried for
cases which are unrelated to connection or session overload problems.
This change fix the retry logic as follows:
* Add an exception to indicate connection problem and raise it
  appropriately from the VIM API client
* Modify the expected exceptions in the retry decorator to include
  only connection and session overload related exceptions

This change also fixes the base class of VimFaultException
(VolumeBackendAPIException -> VimException). This change is required
so that we can handle the exceptions thrown by the VIM API client in
a consistent manner. Currently if we need to handle VIM API related
exceptions, we have to catch both VimException and VimFaultException.
For example, the API for checking active session raises
VimFaultException in some cases and we are handling only VimException.
Due to this, when session expires, the session re-establishment and API
retry fails (intermittently) since the check for active session throws
VimFaultException in some cases which is not handled.

Change-Id: I72cfc7777c3ce693b8598633f822c12c2cee2235
Closes-Bug: #1294598

Reset no_proxy when the node is installed behind a proxy

commit: I6b8e2ba2b7e78fa280283d5ee82d618d4f44ec5a
Author: Zu Qiang
Date: Thu May 22 11:35:00 2014 -0500
Implements: bugfix BUGFIX
Closes-Bug: 1291111/1322200
Reason of the change: The installation will be failure if the network
proxy is set. The reason of the failure is that any REST request sent
to the installed OpenStack itself will be redirected to the proxy
server. By default, the no_proxy is set to localhost only, which needs
to be reset to the localhost + HOST_IP + FLOATING_RANG + FIXED_RANGE.

Changes:

 Add "call export_no_proxy_variables" in stack.sh
     This is used to reset the no_proxy variable after HOST_IP,
FLOATING_RANG, FIXED_RANGE have been set.
     # Reset no_porxy variables
     export_no_proxy_variables

 Add a new function "export_no_proxy_variables" in function_common
The new function will reset the no_proxy variable. And save it in the
shell configuration file. It also creates a new file "noproxy".
The noproxy file will be used by other installation procedure,
e.g. Trove.
   # Update no proxy environment variables
   # no_proxy is set in $USERHOME/.bashrc and $USERHOME/noproxy
   #
   function export_no_proxy_variables {
       export no_proxy=`echo $no_proxy,$HOST_IP,$FLOATING_RANG,$FIXED_RANGE | sed -e 's/,\+/,/g'`
     # Check if the USERHOME is set
       if [[ -z "$USERHOME" ]]; then
           USERHOME=$HOME
       fi
     # Save the no_proxy configuration in the shell rc
       if [[ -n `grep 'no_proxy' $USERHOME/.bashrc` ]]; then
          sed -i "/no_proxy=/c\no_proxy=$no_proxy" $USERHOME/.bashrc
       else
          echo -e "# Reset the no_proxy variables\nno_proxy="$no_proxy >> $USERHOME/.bashrc
       fi
     # Recreating no_proxy file
       echo no_proxy=$no_proxy > $USERHOME/noproxy
       chmod +x $USERHOME/noproxy
   }

Change-Id: I6b8e2ba2b7e78fa280283d5ee82d618d4f44ec5a

subject: Fix difference in index creation for foreign key in MySQL and Postgres
commit_message:
Fix difference in index creation for foreign key in MySQL and Postgres

In some migrations such as:
	* 39cf3f799352_fwaas_havana_2_model,
	* 569e98a8132b_metering,
	* 1064e98b7917_nec_pf_port_del,
	* 5ac1c354a051_n1kv_segment_alloc
A ForeignKeyConstraint is created with the name argument, but in
the corresponding models the name argument isn't used. When the
name argument is used in the constructor, MySQL creates index when
it creates a ForeignKeyConstraint, while with Postgres it does not
create an index.

This causes differences between the models and migrations as well

commit_message:
TEST - Exit collector service if no dispatcher available

When ceilometer collector service start, if there is no dispatcher is
specified, or if all dispatchers are not available, then ceilometer
collector service will trigger exceptions when try to record metering
data, and cannot recover itself automatically even the dispatcher
related backend service is available again, for example, the mongodb
service.

Currently, we will realize that we come across such bug by check the
log, or fail to get expected metering data. But it is not efficient
and inconvenient.

If we can exit the collector service as soon as there is no available
dispatcher when we start it, then we can be alarmed by third party
monitor service, or by check the process status manually.

subject: Payload meta_data is empty when remove metadata
commit_message:
Payload meta_data is empty when remove metadata

When update metadata for a host aggregation, all of the values will
be in the variable of "updates", if remove metadata, the format would
be {"foo": None, "bar": None}; If adding metadata, the format would
be {"foo": "foo1", "bar": "bar1"}.

The current logic of update_metadata() is as following:
1) Get all metadata from variable "updates".
2) Traverse updates to see which values are new added and which needs
to be removed. For the new added values, put the metadata to
variable "to_add"; for the values which need to be removed, just
remove them from metadata.
3) Set the values of variable "to_add" as payload metadata.

The above logic will make the values which was removed from metadata
cannot be in payload, this caused the third party receiver cannot know
which metadata was removed.

The fix was always using the values from variable "updates" as the
metadata for payload as it include values removed and new added.

subject: Address issues with objects of same name
commit_message:
Address issues with objects of same name

There are at least a couple of cases where we may (in the future) introduce
multiple objects that have the same name:

1) When we subclass an object to override internal behavior, presenting
the same version of the object.

2) When we want to introduce multiple versions of objects either via
subclassing or completely separate classes if differences are large
enough to warrant that.

There was a rough plan to support this, however we're currently very
broken. The code before this patch would happily track every one of the
objects with the same name. However, in the case where we see the same
version during 'object registration', we should actually always take the
newest one that we see, replacing the old one.

Also, throughout nova, we have code such as:

from nova.objects import instance as instance_obj

inst = instance_obj.Instance.<....>

This means we're always using the base object, which may or may not be
the correct ('newest') one.

This patch fixes the object registration and adds an attribute to the
'nova.objects' module for every object that is registered, setting the
attribute to the newest version we see.

This will allow us to drop a number of object module imports in favor
of simply importing nova.objects. The example above would become:

from nova import objects

inst = objects.Instance.<....>

Because the object registration ensures objects.Instance is the newest
version, we'll be golden.

Partial-Blueprint: object-subclassing

subject: Remove spaces from SSH public key comment
commit_message:
Remove spaces from SSH public key comment

An SSH key generated by Nova contains the comment 'Generated by Nova'. Older
versions (prior to 0.7.2) of cloud-init trip over the spaces in the comment
and as a result of that the key injected into the root account is not disabled
by cloud-init. Yes, it's a cloud-init bug but it's also a regression in the
sense that older OpenStack installations (Essex and older) don't contain
spaces in Nova generated key comments and thus older cloud-init's are not
affected in these environments.

This patch replaces the spaces with dashes, i.e., 'Generated-by-Nova'.

Spaces were introduced by commit: 114109dbf4094ae6b6333d41c84bebf6f85c4e48
Ubuntu cloud images with cloud-init < 0.7.2: 10.04 LTS and 12.04 LTS
cloud-init bug report: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/cloud-init/+bug/1220273

Closes-Bug: #1297685
Change-Id: I1761f61dfbba58be98351ae4a51884b03268cf09

subject: Fixes yum install-packages command
commit_message:
Fixes yum install-packages command

This small patch resolves Bug 1322278.  The latest
  changes to the yum version of install-packages have
  caused some breakage in the Sahara Image generation
  process.  This bug likely causes breakages in
  any yum-based image generation.

The yum/bin/install-packages script has been modified
  slightly to resolve this problem.  Recent changes
  have added a check for the contents of WHITELIST,
  using the "-eq 0" conditional.  This appears to
  be incorrect, since non-empty lists of yum
  packages are being rejected by this check.

This patch modifies the conditional to use
  "-gt 0", so that any non-zero length WHITELIST
  will cause the script to run the underlying
  yum command, which appears to be the desired
  behavior.

Closes-Bug: #1322278

subject: Defer applying iptable changes when nova-network start
commit_message:
Defer applying iptable changes when nova-network start

When restarting nova-network service, nova-network will initialize iptables and
remove old rules, then add floating ip iptable forward rules one by one.

If there are a lot of floating ips on one host, the process of adding floating
ip rules could last several minutes, which will cause those floating ips that
last added iptable rules disconnected for same time.

This patch defers applying nova-network iptable rule changes until
initialization is done instead of adding floating ip forward rules one by one.

Change-Id: I12651850b44790aef3817fedacae050bff57e364
Closes-bug: 1308390
